doc.title: J.P.Morgan
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/European Luxury and Sporting Goods Weekly Timely PricelessEuropean Luxury and Sporting Goods Weekly Timely Priceless_2025-08-29

passages.text: The European Luxury Goods sector was up \(+5\%\) this week, outperforming the MSCI Europe Index \((- 1\%)\) . The broader sector- wide re- rating was supported by a positive conference call hosted by Swatch \((+5\%)\) to address the US tariff situation (following the introduction of the \(39\%\) duty on Swiss imports), which flagged a very healthy and resilient American consumer throughout the year. This continued into Q3 to date (July+August sales for the Swatch Group were said to be up around \(20\%\) ), remaining robust and showing no push back to the price increases implemented so far. Most luxury stocks rallied, led by those with lighter investor positioning (Burberry up another \(10\%\) , Prada \(+8\%\) , Kering \(+7\%\) , Moncler and LVMH \(+6\%\) ). Talking to investors this week, the tone is indeed becoming more constructive, with most of our conversations looking to revisit the sector, encouraged by the robust data emerging from the US (further confirmed by most American retailers reporting this week), as well as the potential for a recovery of the Chinese consumer (thanks to the wealth effect from rallying stock markets and Macau gaming names showing accelerating trends) from here. We are mindful though that coming out of Q2 reporting the tone on the Chinese cluster, specifically from luxury companies, was still not that positive, noting an overall slowdown of the cluster in Q2 (due to softening tourist spending) and no material changes in current trading, at least as of yet. Brunello Cucinelli \((+3\%)\) this week and up \(1\%\) as we write) also confirmed the continuation of trends (very positive for the brand, as they have consistently been throughout the year) at its H1 results yesterday, with "no material effect on the willingness to buy" in North America, "a very good summer" in Europe and "very positive" performance in China.

The European Sporting Goods sector was up \(+6\%\) this week \((+3\%)\) excluding Puma), outperforming the MSCI Europe Index \((- 1\%)\) . Puma \((+15\%)\) was the best performing stock, rallying on news that the Pinault family may sell its \(29\%\) stake in Puma (worth c. \(900m\) at the current share price) and has approached potential buyers including Anta, Li Ning and Middle Eastern sovereign wealth funds. JD Sports shares were up \(+9\%\) following its Q2 trading update, in which Q2 LFL growth and FY26 profit guidance were broadly in line with market expectations. JD also announced a new £100m share buyback programme, indicating a confident outlook. Among JD's US peers, Dick's Sporting Goods reported very strong Q2 results and raised guidance, seeing broad- based strength and no signs of a consumer slowdown. Foot Locker also reported a sequential improvement in the US, with a positive start to the Back To School season. In contrast, trends at Chinese sporting goods brands were weak, with both Anta and Li Ning seeing a sequential acceleration in Q3 to date, albeit Anta management expects an improvement in demand in September.

See page 8 for analyst certification and important disclosures, including non- US analyst disclosures. J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.
Source:Bloomberg Finance L.P.

Swatch held a conference call to update the market on the US tariffs situation (the \(39\%\) duty on Swiss imports) and implications for the group and the wider watch industry. The comments on the call sparked a rally in the luxury sector as Mr. Hayek noted that: 1) despite the price increases implemented in Q2 (5- 8% varying by brand) and the general macro volatility, the US consumer remains strong, with robust current trading in July and August to date; and 2) a second round of price increases at 5- 10% will be sufficient to absorb the higher duty. Swatch also noted that it had increased its stock levels in North America from six months worth of sales to 10 months. The call focused on the US situation, with no further details on current trading in other regions. See more in our note Take- aways from the US tariff situation call

Brunello Cucinelli reported full H1 results with incremental colour on current trading and profitability. July and August trends were noted to be "very, very positive", along with an "excellent start" of the F/W25 collection. S/S26 campaigns are also developing well, with the men's campaign now completed and the women's campaign ongoing. On regional trends, management on the call noted "no material effect on the willingness to buy" in North America, "a very good summer" in Europe and "very positive" performance in China. Back on H1, sales were \(+11\%\) ex- FX (Q2 \(+11\%\) ), first margin was flat at \(74.5\%\) supported by mix in line with last year, while the EBIT margin slightly declined, - 30bps to \(16.6\%\) due to higher D&A and payroll incidence, partially offset by lower marketing expenses (with some events shifting to H2). Overall H1 EBIT grew \(9\%\) to €114m. On the back of ongoing solid trends with F/W25 and S/S26 campaigns, the group confirmed its FY25 and FY26 guidance.

PVH (covered by M. Boss) Q2 (to end- July) sales came in broadly in line with guidance, \(+1\%\) ex- FX (guide 'flat to increase slightly'), including Calvin Klein \(+3\%\) and Tommy Hilfiger flat yoy. DTC improved to 'flat' (vs Q1 - 3%), with growth in EMEA B&M offset by declines in Americas and APAC, noting "challenging consumer environment" (same dynamics as of Q1). In contrast, e-commerce ('flat' vs Q1 \(+4\%\) ) saw growth in Americas and APAC, offset by a decline in EMEA. Management further added that the improving trends in North America DTC were driven by better product assortment at both CK and TH, stronger marketing communication and increased consumer and end- customer focus. Gross margin declined 240bps yoy to \(57.7\%\) , dragged by an increased promotional environment, unfavourable channel mix, tariff headwinds, higher freight costs and margin headwinds from transitioning previously licensed women's product categories to inhouse wholesale. FY25 guidance for both growth ex- FX and EBIT margin was reiterated. See more from M. Boss here

Kohl's (covered by M. Boss) Q2 (to end of July) sales came in a tad better than expected, with LFL at - 4.2%, vs - 3.9% in Q1. Management noted a sequential improvement month- over- month throughout the quarter, thanks to improved traffic (notably in the digital channel) and proprietary brand sales, with July exiting with flat comp sales growth. By category, the group flagged 1) Sephora sales were \(+3\%\) in 2Q and flat on LFL basis (decelerating vs. 1Q \(+1\%\) SSS), 2) Accessories (excluding Beauty) grew thanks to improvements in Jewelry assortment (+12% growth), 3) Women's outperformed relative to the group, driven by increased private label mix and the re- introduction of the Petites category, 4) Men's and Kid's sequentially moderated due to declines in seasonal assortments (tee's and shorts)

JD Sports reported Q2 results with top- line LFL growth broadly meeting expectations, although gross margin slightly missed due to online controlled price investments. The company anticipates FY26 adjusted PBT to align with market expectations (consensus: £885m), although the tariff impact is not yet incorporated. JD also announced a new £100m share buyback programme, adding to the recently completed £100m buyback. The company will publish its H1- 26 results on 24 September, and expects to share additional details on the tariff then. See more in our note here.

Puma soared nearly \(16\%\) on Monday, August \(25^{\mathrm{th}}\) , on reports that its largest shareholder, the Pinault family (majority shareholders in Kering), is looking to sell its \(29\%\) stake. Bloomberg reports that the family is working with advisers and has approached potential buyers, including Anta, Li Ning and Middle Eastern sovereign wealth funds. This follows a few profit warnings from Puma in recent quarters, with its shares down c. \(53\%\) YTD.

Dick's Sporting Goods (covered by C. Horvers) reported Q2 (May- July) results with comp sales up \(5\%\) yoy (vs \(Q1 + 4.5\%\) ) driven by growth in average ticket and transactions. Gross margin was up 33bp, but EBIT margin was down 110bps to \(12.4\%\) due to increased SG&A costs. The company also confirmed that it was seeing no slowdown in consumer demand. Noting strong Q2 results, the company slightly raised FY25 guidance, now expecting sales of \(13.75 - 13.95bn\) (vs \(13.6 - 13.9bn\) prior), comp sales growth of \(+2.0 - 3.5\%\) (vs \(+1.0 - 3.0\%\) prior) and dil. EPS of \(13.9-\)
14.5 (vs \(13.8 - 14.4\) prior). See more from C. Horvers here.

- Foot Locker (covered by M. Boss) reported Q2 2025 results with a \(-2.0\%\) decline in comp sales, showing an improvement from Q1's \(-2.6\%\) . North America saw a sequential improvement in comp sales, up \(1\%\) compared to Q1's \(-0.5\%\) , with "a positive start to the Back-to-School season in July", while Europe SSS was \(-11\%\) and APAC SSS was \(-6\%\) . The release also flagged "challenging operating environment and soft store traffic trends" particularly in Foot Locker's WSS and international businesses. No guidance or earnings call was provided, as Foot Locker is in the process of being acquired by DKS.

- Anta (covered by Q. Yao) reported full H1 results with sales up \(14\%\) , gross margin down \(70\) bps due to higher online contribution, but EBIT margin \(+60\) bps, driven by efficiency enhancement and operating leverage. On current trading, QTD, core Anta retail sales saw further deceleration vs 2Q, albeit discount levels remained under control. Management expects an improvement in September, with the recovery witnessed in the past week. Retail sales guidance was also updated, with Anta now expected to grow MSD% (vs HSD% prior), Fila sales guidance was maintained at MSD%, while other brands expectations were upgraded to \(>40\%\) (vs \(>30\%\) prior). See more on this in the note by Q. Yao here.

- Li Ning's (covered by Q. Yao) H125 earnings declined by \(11\%\) yoy, with sales up \(3\%\) . August retail sales have shown a sequential slowdown, following a sluggish performance in July and 2Q, with deepened discounts. A&P investments are expected to increase further in H2, although these investments may not yield immediate results. The professional sports category is outperforming, with running and fitness retail sales up \(15\%\) , while basketball sales are down \(20\%\) due to controlled sell-in to maintain brand equity, and sports casual is down \(6\%\) . See more from Q. Yao here

- Management on the move: Lululemon appointed Ranju Das as its Chief AI & Technology Officer, a newly created role, effective September 2. Das was previously the CEO and founder of Swan AI Studios. In addition, Chief Information Officer Julie Averill will depart the company in September to pursue other opportunities.

- Small but interesting: 1) Nike has launched SNKRS Reserve, a new sneaker pre-order system that allows fans to reserve exclusive sneakers in advance to make the drop process more fair and transparent, providing sneaker enthusiasts with a better opportunity to secure limited releases; 2) Nike is laying off less than \(1\%\) of its corporate staff as it restructures its organisation and tries to spark a turnaround. The move follows Nike's new CEO Elliott Hill's effort to realign the organisational structure to suit the next chapter of Nike's growth; 3) Brain Dead x adidas Originals have collaborated to launch the "Japan Flames" collection, which features a range of apparel and footwear inspired by Japanese culture and aesthetics.

- Mon 1st Sept: Hong Kong July retail sales- Tue 2nd Sept: Academy Sports & Outdoors Q2 25 results- Wed 3rd Sept: Macy's Q2 25 results- Wed 3rd Sept: WOSG Trading Update- Thu 4th Sept: Shoe Carnival Q2 25 results- Fri 5th Sept: Zegna H1 25 Results
See more quotes inside weekly.

The Fall- Winter sales season has indeed begun very well, as has the order intake for Men's and Women's collections for the forthcoming Spring- Summer 2026." Brunello Cucinelli, Executive Chairman and Creative Director, Brunello Cucinelli
Source: Company Conference Call, 28/08/2025

The sales recorded during July and August reflect growth in continuation with the trend of the first six months of the year: the data regarding the sell- out of the 2025 Fall- Winter collections confirm a particularly favourable reception by end customers, reinforcing the confidence with which we are facing the second part of 2025."
Brunello Cucinelli, Executive Chairman and Creative Director, Brunello Cucinelli
Source: Company Conference Call, 28/08/2025
In a choppy macro environment, we delivered by intensifying and expanding the impact of our PVH plus execution. And we are making significant progress."
Stefan Larsson, CEO, PVH
Source: Company Conference Call, 27/08/2025

Our lower to middle income customers remain the most challenged, while our higher income customers have proven to be more resilient. These lower to middle income customers continue to prioritize value and are trading down into lower opening price point products."
Michael Bender, Interim CEO, Kohl's Corporation
Source: Company Conference Call, 27/08/2025

Across our regions and fascias, in general we see a resilient consumer, albeit very selective on their purchases. We therefore remain cautious on the trading environment going into H2. For our FY26 profit before tax and adjusting items we expect to be in line with current market expectations, before any indirect impact of US tariffs which we continue to work through."
Regis Schultz, CEO, JD Sports
Source: Company Press Release, 27/08/2025

We are not seeing any signs of slowdown with the consumer. In fact, one of the most exciting things about the quarter that we just delivered is the broad- based nature of the growth that we saw. We saw growth across all of our key segments. So Footwear, Apparel, Team Sports, and Golf, all doing really, really well."
Lauren Hobart, CEO, Dick's Sporting Goods

All authors named within this report are Research Analysts who produce independent research unless otherwise specified. In Europe, Sector Specialists (Sales and Trading) may be shown on this report as contacts but are not authors of the report or part of the Research Department.

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex- Australia and ex- India) and U.K. small- and mid- cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analyst's coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. Morgan's Research website, https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.
